docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision that could have wide ramifications for employment practices, a Federal appeals court has ruled that about 10,000 of Microsoft's current and former temporary workers are entitled to take part in the company's discounted stock-purchase plan. The decision on Wednesday, by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco, determined that a worker hired through a temporary agency could qualify as a Microsoft employee, depending on which company controlled that person's work.

headline.main: Temporary Microsoft Workers Win Stock Ruling

docs.abstract: US Appeals Court rules that about 10,000 of Microsoft Corp's current and former temporary workers are entitled to take part in company's discounted stock-purchase plan; decision determines that a worker hired through temporary agency can qualify as Microsoft employee, depending on which company controls that person's work; ruling in seven-year-old class-action suit says broad group of temporary employees, those working at Microsoft from 1986 through present, are entitled to stock plan; Rob Enderle, vice president at Giga Information Group, which follows computer industry, says if ruling is upheld, it could cost company $15 million to $20 million; Microsoft intends to appeal ruling (M)
docs.snippet: In a decision that could have wide ramifications for employment practices, a Federal appeals court has ruled that about 10,000 of Microsoft's current and former temporary workers are entitled to take part in the company's discounted stock-purchase...

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted in the 19th century to a Victorian cottage, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. On view is her parlor, filled with period furniture. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed today. Admission: $2; 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506. AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West at 79th Street. Exhibition highlights include the Hall of Biodiversity, which focuses on the variety and interdependence of living things. ''The Endurance: Shackleton's Legendary Antarctic Expedition,'' an exhibition documenting Ernest Shackleton's 1914 voyage to the Antarctic, in which the ship became trapped in sea ice, featuring more than 150 photographs by the expedition photographer Frank Hurley. Through Oct. 11. ''Easter Island: Legacies of a People, Masters of Stone,'' four master carvers from Easter Island will be in residence at the museum for 14 days, transforming a 9-foot, 4-ton volcanic rock into a moai (Easter Island head), through Sunday. Once complete, the monumental stone statue -- depicting a giant head and torso -- will be on display through June in the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Hall, first floor. There are free events going on this weekend in conjunction with the carving, including screenings, lectures and performances by Riu Hoko Rapa Nui. Performance times tomorrow at 4 and 7 P.M., and Sunday at 2 P.M. There will also be free events this weekend in conjunction with ''Asian Pacific American Heritage Celebration.'' Tomorrow and Sunday: Daniel Friedman and Sharon Grimberg's ''Miss India Georgia,'' (1997) a video that follows four women in Atlanta's South Asian beauty pageant, at 1 P.M.; ''The Future of Us All in Multicultural Queens, New York,'' a lecture by the urban anthropologist Roger Sanjek at 2 and 3:30 P.M.; a performance by the trio Alankar performing original music combining jazz with North Indian and Western influences, 2:30 and 4 P.M. Other exhibitions: ''Epidemic! The World of Infectious Disease'' examines how best to control the spread of disease worldwide. Through Sept. 6. Imax films are ''Africa's Elephant Kingdom'' and ''Amazon.'' Through June. In the Imax Theater Friday and Saturday nights at 9, ''U2 in 3-D,'' and at 10, ''Pink Floyd's 'Dark Side of the Moon' in 3-D.'' Tickets: $9. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; suggested admission: $8; students and the elderly, $6; children 12 and under, $4.50; under 2, free. A combination ticket including museum admission and one film or any special exhibition: $13; students and the elderly, $9; children 12 and under, $7; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; to buy tickets by phone: (212) 769-5200.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study estimates that 675,000 people lost Medicaid coverage and were without health insurance in 1997 because of sweeping changes in Federal and state welfare programs. The study was issued today by Families USA, a consumer group that has worked closely with the White House on health policy for the last six years.

headline.main: Study Links a Drop in Medicaid To Sweeping Welfare Changes

docs.abstract: New study estimates that 675,000 people lost Medicaid coverage and were without health insurance in 1997 because of sweeping changes in Federal state and welfare programs; study is issued by Families USA, consumer group that has worked closely with White House on health policy for last six years (S)
docs.snippet: A new study estimates that 675,000 people lost Medicaid coverage and were without health insurance in 1997 because of sweeping changes in Federal and state welfare programs.    The study was issued today by Families USA, a consumer group that has...

docs.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has decided not to sell an emergency contraceptive approved last year for sale in the United States and widely available in drugstores nationwide. The company stated in a letter to Planned Parenthood that it had made a ''business decision'' not to fill prescriptions for Preven, which stops ovulation and may prevent fertilized eggs from becoming implanted in the uterus. The drug, manufactured by Gynetics Inc. of Somerville, N.J., is recommended for use up to 72 hours after unprotected sex and is sometimes called a ''morning after'' pill.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Decides Against Selling a Contraceptive

docs.abstract: Walt-Mart Stores Inc has decided not to sell Gynetics Inc's drug Preven, emergency contraceptive approved last year for sale in US and widely available in drugstores nationwide; Wal-Mart, in letter to Planned Parenthood, says it has made 'business decision' not to fill prescriptions for Preven, which is recommended for use up to 72 hours after unprotected sex and is sometimes called 'morning after' pill; Planned Parenthood, critical of Wal-Mart's decision, says it suspects store's policy might stem from pressure from people who say life beings moment egg is fertilized (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a year on the turnaround track, Oxford Health Plans has backed away from the brink of bankruptcy by shedding thousands of loss-making members and raising the premiums paid by the customers who remained. But the big managed care company is still reporting a substantial cash-flow loss on operations and still struggling with the dysfunctional computer systems that nearly sank the company. ''They are not out of the woods yet,'' said Arun Kumar, a health care analyst at Standard & Poor's.

headline.main: Oxford Health Turnaround Is Still a Work in Progress

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans has backed away from brink of bankruptcy a year ago by shedding thousands of loss-making members and raising premiums paid by customers who remained; but company is still reporting substantial cash-flow loss on operations and still struggling with dysfunctional computer systems that nearly sank company; Dr Norman Payson, chief executive who is named chairman, promises shareholders profits later this year, after operating losses in first six months; Payson says makeover is still a 'work in progress' on several important fronts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONGRESS will almost certainly raise the minimum wage this year, probably to $6.15 an hour from $5.15, phased in over two to three years. Democrats, as always, are in full support. So, too, are at least 20 moderate House Republicans anxious about next year's election. But whatever the political attraction, does a higher minimum wage make economic sense? A growing number of economists say yes, though there is reason for Congress to move cautiously, perhaps even creatively.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Minimum wage bandwagon needs some skillful reining.

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on some reasons higher minimum wage makes economic sense; says Congress should move cautiously, perhaps even creatively, in raising wage; says Congress should consider permitting employers to pay $5.15 an hour instead of $6.15 to recent welfare recipients for first six months or so; holds Congress might consider permitting companies to apply some of money they spend on health benefits toward their obligation under minimum wage bill; says there are problems with that approach--young workers are likely to prefer higher wages to health insurance--but it could also help ease pressing and growing social problems; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Choi Yang Sook saw it, her place was in the home, cooking for her husband and cleaning up the house and raising their children. But the Asian economic crisis changed all that, virtually destroying her husband's architectural design business and forcing Mrs. Choi to look for ways to make money herself. So now she is enrolled in a course on how to run a flower shop, and she expects to start her own flower business this year.

headline.main: Seoul Journal; Flower Shop as Symbol: Women's Careers in Bud

docs.abstract: Asian economic crisis has forced South Korean women into job market, and eventual outcome may be more entrepreneurs and even business executives who are women; Korean women have been among most traditional wives and mothers in Asia, but now with family finances crimped, they are acquiring greater economic significance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Drawing Up Plans to Pay for Pills for the Elderly'' (front page, May 10): The Medicare elderly who do not have other insurance often pay substantially more for their prescription drugs (for some drugs reportedly as high as twice as much) as is paid for those on insurance plans, including prices negotiated by the Government for Medicaid and veterans' health care systems. This is essentially a subsidy by the Medicare elderly to the working population and others covered by insurance.

headline.main: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs

docs.abstract: Julian Andelman letter on high cost of drugs for many elderly; contends Medicare elderly who do not have other insurance often pay substantially more for their prescription drugs as is paid for those on insurance plans (May 10 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 9 front-page article ''Many States Slow to Use Children's Insurance Fund'' mentioned that some states couldn't find enough eligible uninsured children to enroll. Almost 400,000 California children are eligible for this new program, yet only 100,000 have signed up. Another 600,000 are eligible for Medicaid but have not enrolled. Overwhelmingly, they are Hispanic children born in the United States, half of whom have at least one parent who is not a citizen.

headline.main: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs

docs.abstract: Dr Patrick T Dowling letter comments on May 9 article on states that are slow to use health insurance fund for children; notes that in California, almost 400,000 children are eligible for new program, yet only 100,000 have signed up
